title: How to Replace the Rollers on a Garage Door

steps.headline: Open your garage door completely.
steps.description: Since it’s easier to work from the roller closest to the bottom of your garage door, you need to open the door before starting work. Lift the garage door open by hand or use the power opener if you have one.

steps.headline: Disconnect the power opener from your garage door if you have one.
steps.description: First, pull the release rope attached to the power opener to release the garage door. For added safety, use a ladder to climb up and unplug the power opener so it doesn’t activate while you’re replacing the rollers. If the power opener is hard-wired into your garage, then turn off the breakers or fuses that lead to it.

steps.headline: Pry open the track near the front of your garage with pliers.
steps.description: Look for a seam near the top of the vertical piece of track. Grab one side of the track with a pair of pliers and bend it to a 90-degree angle. Keep prying open the track until you’ve bent a 1 in (2.5 cm) section. This area will help you pop the rollers in and out of the track. If you don’t have a pair of pliers, you can also use the back side of a claw hammer.Warning: Only pry the track on one side of your garage at a time so you have more control. If you pry both sides at once, the garage door could fall out of the track.

steps.headline: Pull the garage door down so the roller lines up with the track you pried open.
steps.description: Work slowly so you don’t lose control of the door as you pull it down. When the first roller is lined up with the part of the track you pried open, hold the garage door in place with your non-dominant hand. Have a helper hold the door for you so you don’t have to support its weight while you’re working on the rollers. Keep a work table near the side of the garage you’re working on so you can easily access or set down tools.

steps.headline: Pop the first roller out of the track with a flathead screwdriver.
steps.description: Using your dominant hand, slide the end of a flathead screwdriver underneath the round part of the roller. Pull the screwdriver handle up to pry out the roller. It will pop right out from the track so it can be removed. When you take out the roller, that section of the garage door will come out of the track well. Make sure to support the door with your other hand so it doesn’t fall down.Warning: The bottom hinge that holds the roller also attaches to the torsion spring, which prevents your garage door from falling quickly. Hold the door steadily in place so you don’t add additional tension to the spring.

steps.headline: Slide out the old roller and put the new roller in its place.
steps.description: Simply grab the round end of the current roller and pull it out of place. Then, take one of your new garage rollers and slide it into its spot on the hinge. You shouldn’t have to loosen or tighten any screws or nuts to change the roller. Garage door rollers can be purchased from your local hardware store or online. Use steel or hard nylon rollers with 7-10 ball bearings so your garage door opens smoothly and quietly.

steps.headline: Set the roller back in the track.
steps.description: Lift the garage door so the roller and the length of track you bent are lined up again. Make sure the roller is in the center of the track. Hit the end of the roller in the hinge with a hammer to push it back into place. The roller should smoothly move up and down in the track. Sometimes, the roller will pop into the track without using a hammer.

steps.headline: Replace all except the top rollers on the side you’re working on.
steps.description: Pull the garage door down until you reach the next roller. Pry the roller out of the track with your screwdriver so you can replace it with the new one. Keep working until you have 1 roller left on the top panel of your garage door. When you’re finished, open the garage door all the way. Most standard garage doors have 10-12 rollers total. The number of rollers depends on the height of your garage door.

steps.headline: Bend the track closed again.
steps.description: Once you’ve finished the rollers on one side of the garage, use your pliers to close the section of track you bent earlier. Bend it back to its original position so the track is flush at the seam or else your rollers will catch on it.

steps.headline: Repeat the process with the rollers on the other side.
steps.description: Go to the other side of your garage door and bend the area of vertical track near the seam. Pull the garage door so the roller lines up with the bent track, and pop the roller out to replace it. Continue working on the rollers one at a time until you’ve replaced all but the top 2 rollers. Don’t forget to bend the track back into place when you’re finished or else your garage door may come loose.

steps.headline: Place a clamp on the track 1 ft (30 cm) from the bottom of your door.
steps.description: When the garage door is open, secure a hand clamp near the bottom of the door. This will help prevent the garage door from falling down while you replace the roller on top. Ask a helper to support the door for you if you don’t have a clamp.

steps.headline: Pop the roller out of the track with a screwdriver.
steps.description: Climb a ladder so you can easily access the top roller while your garage door is open. Support the garage door above you with your non-dominant hand. Slide the end of a flathead screwdriver underneath the top roller and pry it out from the track. As you pop the roller out of the track, the garage door will drop. Be careful so it doesn’t hit you in the head. Always maintain 3 points of contact with your ladder as you climb it. Otherwise, have a helper hold the ladder sturdy while you work.Tip: If you don’t get enough leverage with a screwdriver, try using the back of a claw hammer.

steps.headline: Replace the old roller with your new one.
steps.description: Pull on the round end of the current roller to pull it out from the top bracket. Once it’s removed, just slide the new roller in to replace it. There will not be any screws or nuts to secure it in place.

steps.headline: Turn the track with your hand to pop the roller back in.
steps.description: Hold the roller bracket in your dominant hand. Grab the section of track next to your roller with your non-dominant hand and twist it away from you. Set the round part of the roller onto the wall of the track and let go of the track. It should easily secure the roller inside. If the track doesn’t easily turn, then bend the track with your pliers as you did for the other rollers.

steps.headline: Repeat the process on the other side of the door.
steps.description: When you finish one side of your garage door, bring your ladder to the other side to change the other top roller. Pop it out of place with your screwdriver and swap the old roller for the new one. Turn the track with your hand and set the roller in place.
